Title: Complete Blood Count
Description: A complete blood count is a blood test used to evaluate your overall health and detect a wide range of disorders, including anemia, infection and leukemia. The test measures several components and features of your blood, including red blood cells.

Title: White Blood Cells
Description: White blood cells help fight infections. If you have high WBC levels, your doctor can deduce that you may have inflammation or infection somewhere in your body. If your levels are low, you still may be at risk for infection.
Range: 4.0 - 10.0 10^3/uL (A microliter is a very tiny amount–one millionth of a liter)

Title: Red Blood Cell Count
Description: Red blood cells deliver oxygen and carbon dioxide throughout your body. They contain hemoglobin and are normally uniform in size and shape. If your RBC count is too low, you may have anemia or another condition (if you have anemia, your blood has fewer red blood cells than normal).
Range: Male: 4.5 - 5.9 10^6/uL; Female: 4.1 - 5.1 10^6/uL (A microliter is a very tiny amount–one millionth of a liter)

Title: Hemoglobin
Description: Hemoglobin is a protein in the blood that allows red blood cells to deliver oxygen to the cells and tissues in the body.

Title: Hematocrit
Description: Hematocrit provides information about how much of your blood is comprised of red blood cells. A low score on the range scale may be a sign that you have too little iron, the mineral that helps produce red blood cells. A high score could mean that you’re dehydrated or have another condition.

Title: Mean Corpuscular Volume
Description: Mean corpuscular volume is the average size of your red blood cells. If they’re bigger than normal, your MCV increases. This may happen if you have low vitamin B12 or folate levels. If your red blood cells are smaller, you may have a type of anemia.

Title: Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin
Description: Mean corpuscular hemoglobin levels refer to the average amount of hemoglobin found in the red blood cells in the body. Hemoglobin is a protein in the blood that allows red blood cells to deliver oxygen to the cells and tissues in the body.

Title: Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration
Description: Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration is the average amount of hemoglobin inside a single red blood cell. Hemoglobin is an iron-rich protein that helps transport oxygen within the blood.

Title: Platelet Count
Description: Platelets are cells that circulate within your blood and bind together when they recognize damaged blood vessel. A platelet count that is lower than normal (thrombocytopenia) or higher than normal (thrombocytosis) is often a sign of an underlying medical condition, or it may be a side effect from medication. If your platelet count is outside the normal range, you'll likely need additional tests to diagnose the cause. It’s dangerous to be below 10,000 platelets per microliter.

Title: Red Blood Cell Distribution Width - Standard Deviation
Description: The standard deviation of the red blood cell distribution width is the measurement of the width of the red cell distribution curve.

Title: Red Blood Cell Distribution Width - Coefficient of Variation
Description: The coefficient of variation of the red blood cell distribution width is a statistical calculation based on both the width of the distribution curve and the mean cell size. It is calculated by dividing the standard deviation of the mean cell size by the mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of the red blood cells and multiplying by 100 to convert to a percentage. Because it is a calculation, the RDW-CV is dependent not only on the width of the distribution curve but also the MCV of the red cell population and may not always reflect the actual variation in red cell size.

Title: Mean Platelet Volume
Description: The mean platelet volume measures the average size of your platelets. Platelets are cells that circulate within your blood and bind together when they recognize damaged blood vessel. MPV closely related to a platelet count test, which measures the number of platelets in your blood.

Title: Neutrophils
Description: Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell that helps heal damaged tissues and resolve inflections. These cells are important because, unlike some of the other white blood cells, they aren’t limited to a specific area of circulation. They can move freely through the walls of veins and into the tissues of your body to immediately attack all antigens.

Title: Lymphocytes
Description: Lymphocytes are a type of white blood cells that help fight off disease.

Title: Monocytes
Description: Monocytes are another type of white blood cell that ingest bacteria and other foreign objects

Title: Esinophils
Description: Eosinophils are a type of white blood cell that function in allergic responses and resisting some infections

Title: Basophils
Description: Basophils are a type of white blood cell that constitute less than 1% of the total white blood count.

Title: Comprehensive Metabolic Panel
Description: The comprehensive metabolic panel is a frequently ordered panel of 14 tests that gives a healthcare provider important information about the current status of a person's metabolism, including the health of the kidneys and liver, electrolyte and acid/base balance as well as levels of blood glucose and blood proteins. Abnormal results, and especially combinations of abnormal results, can indicate a problem that needs to be addressed.

Title: Sodium
Description: Sodium is vital to normal body processes such as nerve and muscle function

Title: Potassium
Description: Potassium is vital to cell metabolism and muscle function.

Title: Chloride
Description: Chloride helps to regulate the amount of fluid in the body and maintain the acid-base balance.

Title: Carbon Dioxide
Description: Carbon Dioxide helps to maintain the body’s pH levels

Title: Anion Gap
Description: Anion gap is a way to check the level of acid in the blood

Title: High-Density Lipoprotein
Description: A type of cholesterol

Title: Total Bilirubin
Description: Bilirubin levels are pigments formed from the breakdown of red blood cells which is excreted by the liver.

Title: Total Protein
Description: Total protein count and high counts may be seen in some diseases with an abnormal immune response, some tumors or dehydration.

Title: Globulin
Description: Globulin is made up of different proteins called alpha, beta, and gamma types. Some globulins are made by the liver.

Title: Alkaline Phosphatase
Description: Alkaline phosphates are enzymes found in the liver

Title: Truglycerides
Description: Triglycerides are fatty substances in the blood (compare to CHOL)

Title: Cholesterol
Description: Cholesterol levels measure a patient’s risk of coronary heart disease

Title: Aspartate Aminotransferase
Description: Aspartate amino transferase is an enzyme found in the heart and liver.

Title: Alanine Aminotransferase
Description: Alanine amino transferase (also SGPT) is an enzyme found mostly in the cells of the liver and kidney.

Title: Albumin
Description: Albumin is a small protein produced in the liver, the major protein in serum.

Title: Glucose
Description: Glucose is the primary energy source for the body’s cells

Title: Blood Urea Nitrogen
Description: Blood urea nitrogen is the waste product filtered out of the blood by the kidneys

Title: Calcium
Description: One of the most important minerals in the body- essential for proper functioning of muscles, nerves, and the heart.

Title: Creatinine
Description: Creatinine is waste product produced in the muscles; it is filtered out of the blood by the kidneys so blood levels are a good indication of how well the kidneys are working

Title: Blood Urea Nitrogen/Creatinine Ratio
Description: (see information about BN and CRE2)
